issues.title: Add visual highlight effect for newly available actions
issues.body:
## Summary
When new actions become available (unlocked by meeting requirements), they should have a visual highlight effect until the player interacts with them.

## Proposed Implementation
- Track which actions player has 'seen' or interacted with
- New/unseen actions get a subtle glow or pulsing border
- Effect disappears after:
  - Player hovers over the action, OR
  - Player uses the action, OR
  - Next turn starts (optional)

## Example Use Cases
- Player publishes first paper → 'Submit Paper' action unlocks → highlighted
- Player reaches 30 reputation → 'Strategic' submenu unlocks → highlighted
- New hire types become available after certain turn → highlighted

## Technical Considerations
- Need to track 'seen' actions in GameState or separate tracking
- Could use shader effect or animated border
- Should be subtle, not distracting

## Priority
Nice-to-have - helps player discovery of new options

issues.title: UI Polish: Submenu positioning, escape hints, and cost display
issues.body:
## Summary
Multiple UI improvements from playtesting session to improve game feel and usability.

## Tasks

### 1. Submenu Positioning
- Submenus should visually 'pop out' to the right of the main menu
- Currently submenus appear as centered overlays
- Should feel more like expanding menus (think StarCraft 2 style)

### 2. Escape Key Hints
- Add visual hint showing 'Press ESC to close' or similar
- Add clickable close button (X) to all submenus
- Current: no visual indicator that ESC closes submenus

### 3. Event Popup Cost Display
- Display costs/benefits directly on event choice buttons
- Currently costs only show on hover (InfoBar)
- Should be explicit: 'Emergency Intervention ($30k, 2 AP)'
- Helps players make quick decisions

## Files Involved
- `godot/scripts/ui/main_ui.gd` - submenu display logic
- Various `_show_*_submenu()` functions
- Event popup creation in `_show_event_dialog()`

## Priority
Medium - improves UX significantly but not blocking gameplay

issues.title: Implement business loan repayment system
issues.body:
## Summary
Business loans are currently disabled ('Coming Soon') because they require a repayment system.

## Requirements
1. **Debt tracking** - GameState needs a 'debt' field
2. **Repayment schedule** - X% of money per turn goes to loan repayment
3. **Default consequences** - What happens if you can't pay?
   - Increased doom?
   - Reputation damage?
   - Forced asset seizure?
4. **Multiple loans** - Can you take multiple loans? Interest stacking?

## Current State
- Action exists in `get_fundraising_options()` with `is_stub: true`
- Execution handler returns 'Coming Soon' message
- Gains defined as `money: 75000, debt: 90000` (15k interest)

## Related
This is part of making the financial gameplay more strategic and realistic.

issues.title: Implement /usr/bin/bash threshold punishment mechanism
issues.body:
## Summary
When players reach /usr/bin/bash money, there should be meaningful consequences beyond just not being able to afford things.

## Proposed Mechanics
- Forced layoffs (lose researchers)
- Doom increase from organizational instability
- Reputation hit from financial troubles
- Possible "bankruptcy" game over after X turns at /usr/bin/bash

## From Playtesting
Player noted that reaching /usr/bin/bash doesn't feel impactful enough - the game should punish you for going broke.

issues.title: feat: Add EventService for historical event fetching (#442)
issues.body:
## Summary

Implements the API event fetching system from #442 that loads historical AI safety timeline events and transforms them into game-playable events.

### EventService Architecture
- Fetches events from external API (pdoom-data) with local caching
- Falls back to bundled `historical_events.json` for offline play
- 24-hour cache expiry with manual refresh option
- HTTPRequest-based async fetching with error handling

### Event Transformation
- Converts raw historical data (date, title, category, significance) into game events with costs, effects, and player choices
- Category-aware option generation (organization, research, policy, incident, capability)
- Significance-scaled effects for balanced gameplay
- Preserves source data for reference

### Historical Events Dataset (20 curated events)
**Organizations:** MIRI, FHI, OpenAI, Anthropic, CAIS, Redwood Research, ARC Evals, Alignment Forum
**Capabilities:** AlphaGo, GPT-3, ChatGPT, GPT-4, Claude
**Policy:** Asilomar Principles, Pause Letter, UK AI Summit, EU AI Act, CAIS Statement
**Research:** Superintelligence book, Concrete Problems paper

### Integration Points
- Added `EventService` autoload to project.godot
- `GameEvents.check_triggered_events()` now includes historical events
- Debug overlay shows historical event cache status
- Events trigger based on game year (12 turns/year from 2017 start)

### Data Flow
```
External API (pdoom-data) -> Fetch -> Transform -> Cache -> GameEvents -> UI
```

## Test Plan
- [ ] Game launches without errors
- [ ] Debug overlay (F3) shows "Historical Events: Loaded X events"
- [ ] Historical events trigger at appropriate game turns
- [ ] Event options display correctly with costs/effects
- [ ] Cache persists across game sessions
- [ ] Offline mode works with bundled fallback data

## Files Changed
- `godot/autoload/event_service.gd` - New EventService autoload (532 lines)
- `godot/data/historical_events.json` - Bundled historical events (188 lines)
- `godot/project.godot` - Added EventService autoload
- `godot/scripts/core/events.gd` - Integration with historical events
- `godot/scripts/debug/debug_overlay.gd` - Cache status display

Closes #442

issues.title: chore: Clean up GDScript warnings and style issues
issues.body:
## Summary
During QA testing, a number of GDScript warnings were observed in the Godot debugger console. These don't cause runtime errors but should be cleaned up for code quality.

## Warnings to address
From the debugger output:

- **Integer division warnings** - Multiple instances of `Integer division. Decimal part will be discarded.`
- **Unused local variables** - Variables declared but never used:
  - `event_type`
  - `start_result`
  - `turn_result`
  - `event_id`
  - `research_label` (shadowing)
  - `current_money`
  - `panel`
- **Ternary operator type mismatch** - `Values of the ternary operator are not mutually compatible`
- **Unused parameter** - `doom_percentage` in `update_doom_level()`
- **Iterator naming conflict** - `seed` iterator has same name as built-in function

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All GDScript warnings resolved or intentionally suppressed with comments
- [ ] No new warnings introduced
- [ ] Game still functions correctly after changes

## Notes
These are style/quality issues only - the game runs fine with these warnings present.

issues.title: Implement Event Override System (ADR-001 Compliance)
issues.body:
## Overview

Implement the game-side of ADR-001 (Game/Data Boundary) as documented in pdoom-data. This enables the game to consume events from pdoom-data while maintaining full control over game balance and mechanics.

**Reference**: https://github.com/PipFoweraker/pdoom-data/blob/main/docs/ARCHITECTURE_DECISION_RECORDS.md

## Background

pdoom-data provides 1,194 timeline events with **sensible defaults** for game integration:
- Impact values (cash, stress, reputation, etc.)
- Rarity (common/rare/legendary)
- Flavor text (safety_researcher_reaction, media_reaction)

However, game balance and mechanics should be owned by the game team, not the data team. This issue implements the override layer that lets pdoom1 tune events without requiring changes to pdoom-data.

## The Layered Model

```
pdoom-data (Source)          pdoom1 (This Issue)
------------------          -------------------
Historical facts     --->   (consumed as-is)
Default impacts      --->   Override Layer (tune values)
Default rarity       --->   Override Layer (adjust for gameplay)
Reactions            --->   (consumed as-is, or override)
                            Game Extensions (chains, triggers, scenarios)
```

## Implementation

### 1. Create Override Directory Structure

```
pdoom1/
  data/
    events/
      overrides/           # Per-event tuning
        README.md          # How to use overrides
        example.json       # Template
      extensions/          # Game-only mechanics
        event_chains.json  # A unlocks B
        triggers.json      # Conditional appearance
        scenarios.json     # Mode assignments
      balancing/           # Global tuning
        rarity_curves.json # How rarity maps to probability
        difficulty.json    # Difficulty multipliers
```

### 2. Override Schema

```json
{
  "ai_sandbagging_research_2024": {
    "impacts": [
      {"variable": "cash", "change": -20},
      {"variable": "stress", "change": 15}
    ],
    "rarity": "legendary",
    "pdoom_impact": 8
  }
}
```

Only include fields you want to override. Missing fields use pdoom-data defaults.

### 3. Event Loader Logic

```python
def load_event(event_id: str) -> Event:
    # 1. Load base event from pdoom-data
    base = load_pdoom_data_event(event_id)

    # 2. Apply overrides if present
    if override := load_override(event_id):
        base = deep_merge(base, override)

    # 3. Attach extensions
    base.chain = load_chain(event_id)
    base.trigger = load_trigger(event_id)
    base.scenario = load_scenario(event_id)

    return base

def deep_merge(base: dict, override: dict) -> dict:
    """Override replaces base values, arrays are replaced entirely."""
    result = base.copy()
    for key, value in override.items():
        result[key] = value
    return result
```

### 4. Extension Schemas

**Event Chains** (`extensions/event_chains.json`):
```json
{
  "chains": [
    {
      "trigger_event": "openai_safety_team_exodus_2024",
      "unlocks": ["anthropic_hiring_spree_2024"],
      "delay_turns": 2
    }
  ]
}
```

**Triggers** (`extensions/triggers.json`):
```json
{
  "triggers": [
    {
      "event_id": "major_alignment_breakthrough",
      "conditions": {
        "min_turn": 50,
        "requires_research": 100,
        "probability": 0.1
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

**Scenarios** (`extensions/scenarios.json`):
```json
{
  "scenarios": {
    "hard_mode": {
      "include_events": ["funding_catastrophe_*"],
      "exclude_events": ["alignment_breakthrough_*"],
      "impact_multiplier": 1.5
    }
  }
}
```

### 5. Documentation

Create `docs/EVENT_OVERRIDE_SYSTEM.md`:
- How to add overrides
- When to override vs request pdoom-data change
- Extension system documentation
- Examples and templates

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Override directory structure created
- [ ] Override schema documented
- [ ] Event loader supports overrides
- [ ] At least 3 example overrides created
- [ ] Event chain system implemented
- [ ] Trigger condition system implemented
- [ ] Scenario assignment system implemented
- [ ] Documentation complete
- [ ] CLAUDE.md updated with override guidance

## Benefits

1. **Fast iteration** - Game team can tune balance without data repo PRs
2. **Clear ownership** - Facts in pdoom-data, mechanics in pdoom1
3. **No coupling** - Data updates don't break game balance
4. **Extensibility** - Add game mechanics without touching source data

## Related

- pdoom-data ADR-001: https://github.com/PipFoweraker/pdoom-data/blob/main/docs/ARCHITECTURE_DECISION_RECORDS.md
- pdoom-data CLAUDE.md: https://github.com/PipFoweraker/pdoom-data/blob/main/CLAUDE.md

## Notes

This is a foundational architecture issue. Completing this unblocks:
- Rapid game balancing
- Custom scenarios and difficulty modes
- Event chain narratives
- Community modding (override files are moddable)

issues.title: Multi-Turn Action Delegation System
issues.body:
# Multi-Turn Action Delegation System

## Summary
**PRIORITY: MEDIUM** - Implement multi-turn action sequences that allow delegation of decision-making to staff/managers, creating more strategic AP management.

## Strategic Context
- **Goal**: Enable complex actions like 'advertise -> receive applicants -> interview -> hire'
- **Benefit**: Reduces micro-management while adding strategic depth
- **Timeline**: Beta phase enhancement (post-alpha)

## Vision
Players can initiate longer-term actions that unfold over multiple turns:
1. **Recruitment Process**: Advertise (1 AP) -> Get applicants (2 turns) -> Interview (1 AP) -> Decision
2. **Research Projects**: Start research (2 AP) -> Progress updates (3 turns) -> Results  
3. **Marketing Campaigns**: Launch campaign (1 AP) -> Market response (4 turns) -> Reputation effects

## Current State Analysis
- **Action system**: Single-turn immediate effects (`actions.py`)
- **Staff system**: Static productivity bonuses (`game_state.py`)  
- **Manager system**: Basic unproductivity prevention
- **AP system**: Turn-based allocation with staff bonuses

## Proposed Architecture

### Core Components
1. **ActionQueue System**: Track multi-turn action progression
2. **DelegationManager**: Handle staff-managed action decisions  
3. **ActionTemplate System**: Define multi-stage action patterns
4. **ProgressTracker**: Show player status of ongoing actions

### Implementation Plan

#### Phase 1: Action Queue Foundation
```python
class MultiTurnAction:
    def __init__(self, action_type, stages, delegated_to=None):
        self.stages = stages  # List of action stages
        self.current_stage = 0
        self.delegated_to = delegated_to  # Staff member handling
        
class ActionQueue:
    def __init__(self):
        self.active_actions = []
    
    def process_turn(self, game_state):
        # Advance all active multi-turn actions
        for action in self.active_actions:
            action.advance_stage(game_state)
```

#### Phase 2: Delegation System
```python
class DelegationManager:
    def can_delegate(self, action_type, staff_member):
        # Check if staff has skills for action
        
    def delegate_decision(self, action, options, staff_member):
        # Staff makes decision based on AI/rules
```

#### Phase 3: UI Integration
- **Action Queue Display**: Show progress of ongoing actions
- **Delegation Interface**: Assign actions to specific staff
- **Progress Notifications**: Turn-by-turn updates on action status

## Example Action Flows

### Recruitment (3-4 turns)
1. **T1**: Player spends 1 AP to 'Post Job Advertisement'
2. **T2-T3**: Applications arrive (automatic)  
3. **T4**: Manager reviews applications (if delegated) OR player chooses (1 AP)
4. **T5**: Hiring decision executed

### Research Project (5-7 turns)
1. **T1**: Player spends 2 AP to 'Start Research Project'
2. **T2-T5**: Research progresses (automatic updates)
3. **T6**: Results available, player decides on publication/secrecy (1 AP)
4. **T7**: Effects applied to game state

## Integration Points
- **File**: `src/core/game_state.py` - Add ActionQueue to GameState
- **File**: `actions.py` - Define multi-turn action templates  
- **File**: `ui.py` - Add action queue display components
- **File**: `src/systems/delegation.py` - New delegation management system

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Players can initiate multi-turn actions
- [ ] Actions progress automatically each turn  
- [ ] Staff can be assigned to handle action decisions
- [ ] UI clearly shows action queue status
- [ ] Delegated actions reduce player micro-management
- [ ] AP costs are front-loaded appropriately

## Technical Challenges
1. **Save/Load**: Persist action queue state
2. **Balance**: Ensure delegated actions aren't overpowered
3. **UI Space**: Display action progress without clutter
4. **AI Logic**: Smart delegation decisions by AI staff

## Dependencies
- **Staff Management System**: Requires improved staff skill system
- **Action Framework**: May need action system refactor
- **Manager System**: Enhanced manager capabilities

## Priority: MEDIUM
**Effort**: 1-2 weeks (significant system addition)
**Impact**: Major gameplay depth enhancement  
**Risk**: Medium (complex system with many interactions)
**Timeline**: Beta phase (after alpha stability)

issues.title: Research Quality System (Rushed/Standard/Thorough)
issues.body:
## Summary
Implement research quality toggle that affects research speed, technical debt, and doom.

**Extracted from**: #429 (which covered Tech Debt + Upgrades + Research Quality)

---

## Feature Description

Three quality levels for research actions:

### Rushed
- **Speed**: 2x research generation
- **Cost**: Accumulates technical debt (+2 per turn)
- **Doom**: +1 doom per turn
- **Use Case**: Desperate situations, final push

### Standard
- **Speed**: 1x research generation (baseline)
- **Cost**: No debt
- **Doom**: Baseline doom
- **Use Case**: Normal gameplay

### Thorough
- **Speed**: 0.5x research generation
- **Cost**: No debt
- **Doom**: -1 doom per turn (safer!)
- **Use Case**: Safety-focused builds, early game

---

## Implementation

### Code Changes

```gdscript
# In actions.gd or new research_quality.gd:
const RESEARCH_QUALITY = {
    "rushed": {
        "research_multiplier": 2.0,
        "debt_per_turn": 2,
        "doom_modifier": 1.0
    },
    "standard": {
        "research_multiplier": 1.0,
        "debt_per_turn": 0,
        "doom_modifier": 0.0
    },
    "thorough": {
        "research_multiplier": 0.5,
        "debt_per_turn": 0,
        "doom_modifier": -1.0
    }
}
```

### Files to Modify
- `godot/scripts/core/actions.gd` - Add quality parameter to research actions
- `godot/scripts/core/game_state.gd` - Track current research quality setting
- `godot/scripts/core/turn_manager.gd` - Apply quality modifiers during turn processing
- `godot/scenes/main.tscn` or UI - Add quality selector (radio buttons/dropdown)

### Integration Points
- Technical Debt System (already implemented) - rushed research adds debt
- Doom System (already implemented) - quality affects doom modifiers

---

## UI Requirements
- Radio buttons or dropdown on research actions
- Show trade-offs clearly (speed vs safety vs debt)
- Default: Standard
- Remember last selection

---

## Estimated Effort
1-2 hours implementation + 1 hour testing

---

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Players can select research quality level
- [ ] Research speed scales with quality selection
- [ ] Rushed research accumulates technical debt
- [ ] Thorough research reduces doom
- [ ] UI clearly shows trade-offs

issues.title: Progressive finance and software management system
issues.body:
## Summary
Comprehensive finance management system where players upgrade from pen-and-paper to sophisticated software, with increasing complexity and automation options.

## Context
From playtesting session 2025-11-27 - extensive notes on finance system design.

## Core Concept
Players must manage increasing transaction volume and complexity. Better systems cost money but save time (AP). Creates interesting trade-off between efficiency and cost.

## Progression Tiers
### Tier 1: Manual (Free, High AP Cost)
- Pen and paper ledger
- Manual receipt tracking
- Scientists often forget receipts
- Manual payroll calculation
- High AP cost for basic accounting

### Tier 2: Spreadsheet ($100/year, Medium AP Cost)
- Excel/Sheets
- Formulas reduce errors
- Still manual data entry
- Better visibility
- Medium AP cost

### Tier 3: Basic Accounting ($1000/year, Low AP Cost)
- QuickBooks equivalent
- Automated categorization
- Invoice generation
- Still requires manual review
- Low AP cost

### Tier 4: Automated Payroll ($5000/year + per employee)
- Automatic payroll processing
- Tax calculations
- Direct deposit
- Minimal AP cost

### Tier 5: International Payroll ($15000/year + per employee)
- Multi-currency support
- International tax compliance
- Exchange rate handling
- Very low AP cost

### Tier 6: Enterprise ERP ($50000/year)
- Full automation
- Predictive budgeting
- Fraud detection
- Minimal AP cost, maximum functionality

## Required Initial Setup
Players must establish (or have in starting config):
- **Bank account** - where money lives
- **Email** - for communications
- **Tracking system** - how they know their balance (even if just mental math)

## Finance Actions & AP Costs
### Review Transactions (AP varies by system)
- Tier 1: 2 AP per 10 transactions
- Tier 6: 0 AP, auto-approved unless flagged

### Chase Missing Receipts (AP varies by culture)
- Some researchers forget receipts
- Requires follow-up
- Better culture = fewer missing receipts

### Approve Expenses (AP varies by system)
- Tier 1: Manual calculation and approval (high AP)
- Tier 6: Auto-approval with smart rules (0 AP)

### Payroll Processing (AP varies by system)
- Tier 1: Calculate hours, taxes, write checks (5 AP)
- Tier 4+: Automated (0 AP)

## Budget Management Features
### Project Budgets
- Researchers propose projects with budgets
  - Compute hours needed
  - Time estimate
  - Effort required
  - Travel for conferences
- Player approves/modifies budget
- Track spending vs budget
- Overspending warnings

### Recurring Expenses
- Rent, utilities, subscriptions
- Players must anticipate and plan
- Can doom yourself with commitments
- Example: Employee severance, lease agreements

### Commitments & Consequences
- Firing employees requires severance pay
- Breaking lease = penalty
- Subscription contracts
- Loan repayment schedules

## UI Enhancement Tie-In
Each software upgrade also enhances the game's UI:
- Tier 1: Basic text display
- Tier 3: Charts and graphs
- Tier 6: Beautiful dashboards, predictive analytics

## Complexity Scaling
As lab grows, transaction volume increases:
- 1-5 employees: ~50 transactions/month
- 5-20 employees: ~200 transactions/month  
- 20+ employees: ~500+ transactions/month

Without upgrades, this becomes unmanageable.

## Strategic Depth
### Trade-offs
- Hire admin staff OR buy better software?
- Cheap manual processes OR expensive automation?
- Focus budget on research OR infrastructure?

### Failure States
- Overdraft from missed payments
- Tax penalties from errors
- Researcher frustration from slow reimbursement
- Audit problems from poor records

## Implementation Phases
1. **Phase 1**: Basic transaction tracking and manual system
2. **Phase 2**: Software upgrade tiers 2-4
3. **Phase 3**: Project budgeting system
4. **Phase 4**: Advanced automation and ERP
5. **Phase 5**: UI enhancement tie-ins

## Related Systems
- Upgrades overhaul (#475)
- Project/research system (needs creation)
- Employee management
- Budget planning

## Design Principles
- Don't simulate actual accounting (boring)
- Represent complexity abstractly (transactions/month, AP cost)
- Make upgrades feel worth it
- Create genuine strategic choices
- Reward planning and investment in infrastructure

## Priority
High - core economic gameplay loop

## Notes
This is a major system that touches many parts of the game. Should be designed carefully and implemented incrementally.

issues.title: Discoverable frontier labs and organization emergence system
issues.body:
## Summary
Re-add the ability to discover frontier labs and other organizations. Organizations instantiate invisibly and start contributing to game effects, becoming discoverable as player gains fame/reputation.

## Context
From playtesting session 2025-11-27. The AI safety field shouldn't be just the player - there should be a dynamic ecosystem.

## Mechanics
### Silent Instantiation
- Organizations spawn at game start or during play
- They have their own budgets, researchers, projects
- They affect global variables (P(doom), capabilities progress, etc.)
- Initially invisible to player

### Discovery Threshold
- Player discovers orgs through:
  - Reputation milestones
  - Publishing in same areas
  - Conference attendance
  - Media coverage
  - Direct investigation actions

### Early Discovery Rewards
- "You discovered DeepMind before they became famous!"
- Early collaboration opportunities
- Recruitment from their staff
- Track their progress

### Observable Threshold
- Low observability: only know big labs (OpenAI, DeepMind)
- High observability: discover small research groups, startups
- Reward: information is valuable for planning

## Benefits
- Dynamic, living world
- Reconnaissance has value
- Surprise and discovery
- Realistic ecosystem

## Related Systems
- Reputation system
- Organization tracking (needs refactor)
- Event system

## Priority
Enhancement - adds strategic depth and world-building
